comments.commentBody: The economic side of our medical system is in shambles. Consumers are caught in the middle of an arms race between medical providers and insurers in which prices keep going up but in which insurers never pay the list price, only the uninsured and out-of-network do. There is normally a negotiated rate between insurer and provider which is considerably lower than the list price. If we dispensed with this and went to a truth in pricing system, we could make a dent in the problems identified in the article. I normally pay for my providers, as they are usually out of network, and I have never found the doctor's charges to be excessive or unreasonable. But I know in advance what the charge will be and am not charged unreasonably. If providers moved to a truth in pricing system, posting the cash rate, that would go a long way to solving this problem.

What we all need to know is that Doctors do not work for the hospitals.  They are all independent contractors, not employees. Hospitals are memly physical plants.  The contract with just about everyone who works there. It makes a lot more profit for the hospitals and shields them from medical malpractice.
Actually, many doctors are now employed by hospitals to reduce their administrative expenses.
We are not all independent contractors. That is false.
Good piece. Thanks.

Any reputation Charlie has for arrogance is in large part due to his portrayal in "Running the Sarah." I am told that -- not surprisingly --  the film was cut to exaggerate his actions in order to add drama to the story.  I have know Charlie for five years. Never have I known him to be arrogant.

I think you may not understand the current context at UW Madison, which to be fair is reflected in the division in the rest of the nation.  The fact is there have been MANY racist incidents on campus last Spring and continuing into the Fall. This month the number of reported hate & bias incidents have sky rocketed. This is all a matter of public record.  Mr. Koenig, Hayes and Hill are speaking out against the racism on campus and using their platform as athletes to be leaders.  The fact that they are emerging as leaders is in fact legitimate news since it is rare.

I think his point is that while it is a very liberal city from the perspective of votes & political affiliation, it is centered in Wisconsin, which is a very conservative state, and the fact is it is a predominantly white institution.  70% of undergrads at Madison come from the state of Wisconsin, and not a small number from towns without a single person of color, Muslim or even Jewish person.  There are many people in Madison who are conservative, and there have been many racists incidents on campus lately. So the actual story is quite nuanced.

These are gifted young men, gifted as students, gifted as athletes, and gifted as articulate spokespeople for justice. When I was young and a student at UC Berkeley, I participated in the Free Speech Movement. But I didn't have a platform to express my opinion beyond marching with my fellow students. Nigel, Jordan, and Bronson do, and I'm glad they are taking advantage of it. And I am also a big fan of Badger basketball.

I don't know if this will hold up if challenged but whenever I sign one of those "I am responsible for uncovered charges" agreements that you're compelled to sign before being treated I always insert "provided I am told in advance that any service or medication is not covered by my insurance, or not customarily covered by insurance..."

People don't know, for the most part, that hospital bills are negotiable. One of my friends, who was uninsured at the time, was hospitalized for a rather expensive emergency surgery. He was hit with an astonishing bill which his brother went in and "negotiated" for him. The hospital wrote off most of the bill, leaving him with a balance of 10K which is about 2K less than he would have paid for insurance for the year. It's being paid off $100 a month.

I knew Condi had 2 E's, but where to put them? I tried 2 L's before 2 Z's. Also RBG before ABA. My guess is she'll wait four more years to retire... Did not like EYE UP. Nobody says that, unless they do, but I've heard plenty of stuff and never heard that one. And yeah, names. But I managed to finish IN AN HOUR, which is okay for me, for a Friday. Smiled at BABALU!

I voted against Trump, just so we're clear. But to answer your question, people who are dissatisfied with our current insurance high price/high deductible insurance mess voted against Hillary because she promised to continue Obamacare. Bill Clinton, in an unguarded moment recently, called Obamacare a crazy system that hit people with high premiums and high deductibles. He was right. I'm sorry Hillary didn't get in because she almost certainly would have come up with a better solution. She and Bill know it's a mess so she probably just said she'd continue Obamacare, as it stands, to get elected.
Actually, many doctors are now employed by hospitals to reduce their administrative expenses.

It has nothing to do with Obamacare. Any private insurance plan a worker gets from his employer has in-network and out-of-network providers. Obamacare has much to commend it and the wrinkles that cause frustration could be ironed out if Republicans were not so uncaring and recalcitrant.

and Elke

Worse than the doctor being out of network is the extortionate fee that many doctors charge under these circumstances. The fee in this case was for $1,620 for what sounds like less than an hour of work. In such cases the fee should be submitted to an arbitration board not in the control of the doctor or the hospital. Excess fees such as this should policed by the state medical association with suspension of a medical license being one of the penalties.

The bill isn't really explained. Usually they give an explanation of benefits (EOB) that could have given us some insight to the bill. It's not really surprising if that was his total bill for stay. You have things like the room, laboratory tests (doctors/techs/phlebotomy), telemetry equipment, nurses, medical assistants, scribes, receptionist, security, janitors. The emergency room is not cheap but rest assured that emergency room physicians do not make thousands per hour. This truly is another blame the doctor for needing to make a high salary when the insurers and hospital admin skim the 20% of what you pay without doing a thing and get filthy rich.
Used boneless leg of lamb. It was great. Added some cayenne pepper to liven it up and also carrots for the last hour of cooking.
I agree!  I too had clipped this recipe when it was first published and thought it the BEST apple cake recipe EVER!!  But about 10 years ago it went missing ;-(   SO HAPPY it has resurfaced!!

I "dry age" my steaks by salting and placing on a rack for two or more days at room temperature, turning twice daily. They firm up, take on a deep maroon color, and become naturally tender. I only buy from a butcher case where the steaks are already out in the open air.

They only need to be seared to be perfect. There is never the squishy bright red cold stuff inside. I even like them raw! :)

A cheap single burner portable electric stove out on the patio solves the smoke problem.

I broke both bones in my ankle. We confirmed the hospital we were going to go to was in network - nobody should have to do that when they're in shock and pain. I was examined in the ER, then scheduled for an operation the next to repair the ankle with a plate and pins. The ER doc was out of network, the blood tests labs were out of network (it was split between 2 different ones!), and the anesthesiologist was out of network. By some stroke of luck, the orthopedic surgeon was a teaching fellow and my surgery day was one of the two days he came to that hospital. The out of network anesthesiologist charged more than the surgeon and the surgeon's fee included 6 follow-up office visits. And that's when we first heard those two dreaded words: balance billing. They wanted another $1200 from us. Their office said they weren't going to adjust the cost at al, and would report us to the credit agencies if we didn't pay in full. It is a medical carjacking. Out of the $40,000 total cost for a 2-day stay in the hospital and the operation ($10 for one multi-vitamin!), the balance billing, the deductible and the co-pays added up to $14,000.

That's when we realized the American medical system was even more broken than my ankle. And in need of greater repair.

It is absurd that any citizen of the richest country in the world would lose their home over medical bills when they had 'medical insurance'. You folks need to go on strike, demonstrate, write all of your elected representatives, and join Bernie Sanders' movement.

I am Canadian. Our healthcare system is not perfect, but nobody in Canada suffers what you have suffered.

PS. And our taxes are not all that much higher, although it is almost impossible to get comparative figures that include what Americans pay in extra healthcare premiums. Poor people here pay little in the way of income taxes, and are fully covered for healthcare. How can removing the profit from healthcare not help with costs?

I live in Europe, Denmark. - We have "total Obamacare". This means that all hospital treatments and doctor treatments are totally free for everyone. We do not have employer-paid plans for working people and privately paid plans for the rest of the population. We are all part of a tax funded system, and the hospitals are run by the government. - When absolutely the whole population is a part of the system then we do not have any kind of problem with "pre existing conditions" and we do not have any problem with younger people staying on the parents plan. Because everybody is covered for everything. The average cost per "member" of the system gets much lower when absolutely everybody is included automatically when they are born. And since everybody is covered for everything we do not have any insurance company in our plan. The government is the insurance company. Total average cost per "member" is about 50 percent of US cost and we have just as high quality treatment as US do. - You can never make "Obamacare" cheaper og better without using this common european model.

What a lie! This has nothing in common with Obamacare, total or partial! Obamacare did not build any public health like you described, just pay part of the insurance plan and give free revenue for the health company. European public health systems are not total Obamacare! Only Switzerland can be compared with Usa system...
Tell that to the people who fell prey to the slick anti-Obamacare advertising campaign. They truly seem to believe that healthcare is a finite, limited good that will not suffice if extended to all.

Hear, hear!

I worked in Denmark as a postdoc in the mid 1990s and needed a minor surgery. The hospital kept me an extra day when they heard that I loved alone and had no family in town. They paid a cab to take me home, and for a next one month, a nurse came to my house to change the dressing. Think that would happen in "we are number 1" USA?

To Tracy----You failed to explicitly mention the insurance companies which make profits by charging large premiums (to pay high executive salaries) and then decline to pay for services rendered.  At least the physicians who have given the necessary care have spent 6-8+ years after college (with attendent costs) to learn what's necessary to know in order to deliver that care.  Medical "high status" isn't given, it's earned.  Single-payer system, yes!

Doctors go to 4 years of undergrad 4 years of medical school to graduate with around $200k in debt with 6% interest. They then are required to do a residency working 80 hours/wk for $52k/yr (~$13/hr) for another 3 to 7 years. Pay of $190k does not start till the early 30s. Then the young board certified physician has to pay off all that debt, make up for lost savings/retirement, and go on to the American dream of a house and supporting a family.

I know that $190k salary looks high, but when you see what goes into it, it is justified.
